Prunus salicina can be grown in regions with hot summers, although it may require additional irrigation during hot and dry periods. Mild winters should not be a problem for Prunus salicina, as long as the temperature does not drop below freezing (-1°C) for extended periods.

In your region, it may be necessary to choose a cultivar of Prunus salicina that is well-suited to hot summers and that has good drought tolerance. Additionally, you may need to provide some shade to the tree during the hottest part of the day to prevent sunscald and water stress.

It's always a good idea to consult with a local nursery or agricultural extension service when selecting fruit trees to ensure that you choose a variety that is well-suited to the specific conditions in your area.
